subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Use of half-letters
msgSnippet: Count me in, I could use (some might say: I m in desperate need of) some hand writing practice. I have to agree with Benct, the internet is much faster and
messageBody:
Count me in, I could use (some might say: I'm in desperate need of) some
hand writing practice.

I have to agree with Benct, the internet is much faster and reliable
than the post.

That said I know how you feel about computerisation.
There are days I just want to chuck the them out the window.
Not that I have any desire to go back to the old disconnected times.
But there is something to be said for paper, there aren't many other
non-volatile mass storage devices that don't require batteries.
Plus all the fonts you need are pre-installed for your convenience. :)

If you do decide on a scan/upload system perhaps a rota would work?
Each week a participant adds a letter until we get to the last one and
then start over?
That would keep roughly the same pace as with the post but without the
danger of letters going missing en route.

Benct Philip Jonsson wrote:
>
> On 2007-09-19 pgabhart wrote:
> > I don't know if this would work today since people are so
> > computer-oriented, but reading other people's handwritten
> > QS is very good practice in my opinion.
>
> In a way it would work even better today: anyone with a
> scanner (most people have direct or indirect access to them
> today, I'd believe, since many printshops and the like offer
> scanning at a small cost) can scan their QS and make it
> available to read for anyone with an internet connexion, and
> Google and others offer somewhere to upload at no cost.
>
> : /|
> : _| | /BP
> : \|
>
>

Not that I have any desire to go back to the old disconnected times.

Plus all the fonts you need are pre-installed for your convenience. :)
